Award.AbstractNarration:
This research continues and extends work on subtle gaze direction - a novel technique that combines real-time eye- tracking with image-space modulation to direct a viewer's gaze about a digital image. This proposed project aims to pursue research in subtle gaze direction for dynamic scenes. This is a natural extension of viewers gaze pattern for static scenes. The work will seek improvement in search task performance. Advances in this area are important for many applications from locating anomalies in medical images to identifying camouflaged targets in a scene. The approach will use automatic feature detection algorithms. The project will also address issues relevant to improving information recall. This will involve studies to determine the impact of subtle gaze direction on spatial information recall for images and spatial-temporal information recall for dynamic scenes. The work will also explore gaze direction in the presence of more overt stimuli.

The project is designed to enable high quality interdisciplinary research that links technology design with health-based applications. The topics addressed are highly interdisciplinary and will require interaction with faculty and mentors from a number of disciplinary areas. The program will create new opportunities for undergraduates to study health and human behavior using the technology. The PI will pursue two curriculum development projects that are closely related to this research endeavor aimed at computer science and non- computer science majors. The courses are continually refined by inclusion of state-of-the- art computer graphics research and techniques. The Principal Investigator also plans to develop a new course on applied perception in graphics and visualization. In both cases, students are exposed to a broad topical area that draws upon human vision, computer graphics and visualization. The courses are expected to attract students from Rochester Institute of Technology's many programs in imaging related science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ability to predict and guide viewer attention has important applications in computer graphics, image understanding, object detection, visual search and training. Under this award the concept of subtle gaze manipulation was studied. Subtle gaze manipulation uses eye-tracking technology and brief modulations presented to the peripheral regions of the field of view to guide viewer attention about a display in a manner that has minimal impact on the viewing experience.

The research team conducted a series of experiments which highlight the benefits of using covert approaches for guiding viewer attention. In particular, these studies revealed that: 

  • subtle gaze manipulation significantly improves the viewer’s recollection of the spatial organization of digital images (findings presented at ACM Eye Tracking Research and Applications Conference (ACM ETRA 2012)).

  • gaze manipulation can be used to help viewers correctly reconstruct the order of events (findings presented at ACM Symposium on Applied Perception (ACM SAP 2012)).

  • guiding the attention of novices using the recorded eye movements of an expert radiologist as they try to identify abnormalities in mammograms results in significantly better performance than a control group without gaze guidance (findings presented at ACM Eye Tracking Research and Applications Conference (ACM ETRA 2012)).

  • gaze manipulation can be used to facilitate password recollection (findings presented at ACM Eye Tracking Research and Applications Conference (ACM ETRA 2016)).

The research team also:

  • extended the concept of gaze manipulation beyond digital imagery and demonstrated a prototype system for guiding attention in controlled real-world environments (findings presented at ACM Symposium on Applied Perception (ACM SAP 2013)).

  • devised strategies for automatically selecting regions of the scene where it is beneficial to draw the viewer’s attention to in order to improve their spatial recollection (findings presented at ACM Symposium on Applied Perception (ACM SAP 2015)).

  • developed a computational framework for perceptually optimized computer graphics (findings presented at the International Conference on Computer Graphics Theory and Applications (GRAPP 2014)).

  • developed a framework for collaborative eye tracking for image analysis applications (findings presented at ACM Eye Tracking Research and Applications Conference (ACM ETRA 2014)).

  • devised novel techniques to address the challenge of analyzing the data from multiple individuals looking at the same real-world scene (initial prototype presented at ACM Symposium on Applied Perception (ACM SAP 2014), more comprehensive system presented at ACM Eye Tracking Research and Applications Conference (ACM ETRA 2016)).

A detailed review of all publications (at the time) resulting from this grant was presented during an ACM SIGGRAPH 2014 course titled "Attention-Aware Rendering, Mobile Graphics and Games." 

This award also supported one Ph.D. student who successfully defended his dissertation in 2016, and several MS students and undergraduates who have appeared as co-authors on the various publications resulting from this award. The students come from diverse backgrounds including underrepresented groups in computing.

The major education activity has been the development and delivery of a course on applied perception in graphics and visualization which has been offered several times at Rochester Institute of Technology. The course materials have been shared with other members of the applied perception research community.

The research team has been heavily involved in outreach activities over the course of this project including:

  • 'Career Day' presentations at Bay Trail Middle School. The PI spoke to 7th and 8th graders about research in computer graphics, eye-tracking, and applied perception. He also described his career path and the importance of math and reading skills and exposure to information across many disciplines.

  • ‘Science Fun Day’ presentations and demonstrations at Quest Elementary School.

  • The PI presented his research on gaze manipulation to a gathering of high school teachers at the annual 'Computer Science for High School (CS4HS)' conference at Rochester Institute of Technology.

  • Annually, the PI and his students presented several exhibits at RIT's annual innovation and creativity festival which is open to the general public and attracts over 25,000 visitors to campus.

  • The PI and his students regularly host lab tours and demonstrations for various RIT events including RIT College and Careers - a two-day conference targeting high-school seniors, and RIT Computing Exploration - a program for incoming freshmen to experience the computing field before declaring a specific major.

  • The PI and his students hosted lab visits for Native American high-school students in partnership with the RIT Native American Future Stewards Program.
